results.title: The Dandelion
results.brief_description: A study using time-lapse and microcinematography of the Dandelion as a typical example of the group, Compositae, including the processes of cross and self-pollination, fertilisation and germination.

results.title: The Dancing lion: an African folktale
results.creator_credit: George Lindsay, FilmFair Communications and Tommy McClelland
results.brief_description: Musicologist Andrew Tracy and a group of African musicians introduce African rhythms and demonstrate how each of the twelve beats sounds alone, in combination and in crossed rhythms. Tracy tells a group of children a folktale about how a husband and a rabbit enchant a lion with music, changing a dinner-hunting beast into “the dancing lion” and thus freeing the wife. He illustrates the role of music in African storytelling by having children clap and chant responses as he relates the tale of a dancing lion.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Lindsay, FilmFair Communications and Tommy McClelland

results.title: The Dancing fleece
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit, Frederick Wilson and Carl Koch
results.brief_description: Illustrates, through the medium of ballet, the manufacturing processes for woollen fabrics. A wool worker visits a fair and, looking into a slot machine, sees clock-work puppets come to life. He and the puppets, now ballet dancers, interpret the various stages in wool production in terms of ballet. The film features dancer and choreographer, Harold Turner, and the Saddlers Wells Ballet Company.

results.title: The Dancing feet
results.creator_credit: V. Shantaram, Films Division, Government of India and A. Bhaskar Rao
results.brief_description: The role of the dance in Indian life. People of rural India singing and dancing together. Dances of different regions brought together in this film include Gujerat, Kulu, Kerala, eastern India, Deccan Kashmir and Rajasthan and the Punjab.

results.title: The Dancing class
results.brief_description: Captures the atmosphere of dedication at the Robert Pomie Ballet School. Shows a ballet class at work featuring seventeen year old Sylvia Polvolgyi. Taken in sequence the film shows the daily routine of the cleaner at work in the studio, the girls arriving, changing and going to the bar to warm up and finishing with an adagio and allegro. Camera by Tom Cowan and Nigel Buesst; music by George Dreyfus. (Gold Award, Documentary Section, 1964 Australian Film Awards)

results.title: The Dance of the angels: ceramic sculptures of John Perceval
results.creator_credit: Patrick Ryan, Eltham Films and Tim Burstall
results.brief_description: Camera movement and film editing are combined to animate the ceramic figurines of John Perceval. He created his angels “more or less as symbols of the world’s survival.” An intangible element common to all Perceval’s angels is their spirit of humanity. These ceramic sculptures are disting- uished by their beautiful modelling, and their lustrous red copper glaze with its uncanny depth and beauty. Perceval does not devote himself exclusively to ceramic sculpture; he gives equal time to painting and has won the McCaughey and Vizard-Whollohan Prizes, and shared the Wynne Prize in 1961. Photography by Gerard Vanderberg; music by Dorian Le Gallienne.

results.title: The Dam builders: beavers and man
results.creator_credit: L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Broadcast
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World We Live In”.
A comparison of the ecological changes brought about by the dam building activities of two species of mammals - humans and the beaver. It shows that all life is interdependent and points out how humans are damaging the ecological balance of nature whereas the beaver, although bringing change to its area, is not. Shows beavers in north America and engineers in Africa. Narrated by Joseph Julian.

results.title: The Dam at Nagarjunasagar
results.creator_credit: Equinox Films, Carousel Films and Gene Leashinger
results.brief_description: South of Hyderabad, India, astride the mighty Krishna river, stands the most massive masonry dam ever constructed. In an architectural feat which parallels the building of Egypt’s Pyramids, 30,000 men, women and children worked day and night for 14 years to complete it. Nagarjunasagar is three miles across, 400 feet high and forms one of the largest man-made lakes in the world.

results.title: The Dairy farm
results.brief_description: In this film we visit a mid-western American dairy farm; we watch the farmer engaged in feeding his cattle, milking the cows, preparing the milk for marketing, and such seasonal operations as cultivating, haying, and storing fodder in the silo.
results.description: In this film we visit a mid-western American dairy farm; we watch the farmer engaged in feeding his cattle, milking the cows, preparing the milk for marketing, and such seasonal operations as cultivating, haying, and storing fodder in the silo.
